data.title: Learn your olives: the best olive oil varieties in the world!
data.meta_description: What are the best olive oil varieties in the world? Learn everything you need to know about the best olive oil varieties in the world!
data.text:
Hello, my little candle in the wind!

Today we are learning something useful. Something you can use at your home dinner, be a smarty, itâs sexy. Weâll make learning easy and fun. You will absorb the information like Winston Churchill absorbed his bottle of Champagne (Pol Roger). Are you ready? Today, we are learning about the most planted and used olive oil varieties in the world (and one local hipster olive, because why not)!

Olive oil is an essential part of your kitchen. Whether you fry, roast, make salad or dough, you need your olive oil! We use it in large amounts and thank the Olympian gods for that! But rarely we ask ourselves about the technology behind it, heck, we donât even know the most planted olive oil varieties in the world. Weâll change this really fast, and to be honest, their names sound like someoneâs making love to your ear. Grrrrrr! Forget about Chardonnay and Cabernet (weâll donât, rather pour one good glass for me too) and learn about Leccino, Pendolino, Picual â¦

Where does your olive oil come from?

First, we need to know where your olive tree comes from. The main producing regions all need that fine Mediterranean climate, they just feel good in it, I mean who wouldnât? But also, they need changing seasons, so replanting the Sahara Desert with olive trees will not work. But then again, youâre the boss, if you feel like it, do it, I wonât judge. The main oil producing countries are Spain, Greece, Italy, Tunisia, Portugal, the US (California) and others (no Germany, for now at least).

The most planted varieties

If you weâre an olive oil farmer, you would want the best olive oil in large quantities to sell, right? Weâll thatâs what everyone is searching in quality olive oil varieties. They need to get the best oil every single year. Some mass market olive oil varieties like Picual (Spain), have very high yields, and much oil in one olive, and therefore produce large quantities of (mostly cheap) olive oil. Other fancy varieties like Pendolino (Italy) have small size olives, and often produce rich olive oils of good quality. The most planted olive and common olive oil varieties are: Picual (Spain), Cornicabra (Spain), Koroneiki (Greece), Kalamata (Greece), Leccino (Italy) and Pendolino (Italy). The vast amount of olive trees in the world are those.

The varieties

Leccino

Here comes the Italian, “mi scusi”, here comes Leccino! Heâs an allrounder, very adaptable and therefore spread across the world (just like the Italians). Olive oils are somewhat like wine (or grapes) when harvested. When they are harvested early, they often have fresh, green, herbaceous, apple, citrus like aromas. On the other side, when theyâre harvested later, they become sweeter and softer. This is very true for the Leccino olive, EVVOâs picked earlier are really spicy, green, bitter and herbaceous, just like my life so far (just kiddinâ itâs not green or herbaceous).

Oblica

This one is a hipster. There are a lot, I mean a lot, of olive oil varieties in the world, with new ones to arise every year. It wouldnât be nice to leave out those little cute hipster olives from our list. Therefore, here is the hipster from Croatia, Oblica. The name comes from its round shape, and itâs domestic to the Adria. You will not find it ever in your lifetime, but hey, you heard of it, right?

There it is my little candles. We learned the most planted olive oil varieties in the world. Next time you buy your oil, read the label, pretend itâs the thousand bucks Pinot Noir, and read everything on it. Where it came from, whatâs the variety, who made it, how they made it! The first step of being a cool gastronomy hipster is to read the products youâre buying. We are here to help with information, and as always, my little candle in the wind, sharing is caring! Share or donât because you are one special little olive!
